unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Simulating the Game of Craps
question_text: The game of Craps is a casino game in which a player rolls a pair of $6$ -sided dice. On the first roll of the dice, if the sum is $7$ or $11$ , it is called a “natural” and the player wins. Sierra wants to try the game but wonders what the probability of a “natural” is. Unfortunately, she is really bad at probability so she programs her computer to simulate $10,000$ tosses of a pair of dice and use the results to calculate the probability of a “natural”. Which of the following would Sierra most likely conclude as a result of this simulation? Why?

choices.text: Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is 0.001 0.001 . Although the true probability is 0.03 0.03 , 10 , 000 simulations 10 , 000 simulations is not a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with any degree of accuracy.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is 0.04 0.04 . The true probability is 0.06 0.06 but 10 , 000 simulations 10 , 000 simulations is not a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is 0.080 0.080 because 10 , 000 simulations 10 , 000 simulations is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is 0.083 0.083 .

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is 0.113 0.113 because 10 , 000 simulations 10 , 000 simulations is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is 0.111 0.111 .

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is 0.221 0.221 because 10 , 000 simulations 10 , 000 simulations is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is 0.222 0.222 .
